docs.title: Ctrl C + Ctrl V Hackathon
docs.text: Welcome to the Ctrl C + Ctrl V Hackathon! This documentation contains all the problem statements and guidelines you need to participate.

docs.title: 🎯 Key Details
docs.text:
Detail Information Start 1:00 PM, Wednesday, 11th February 2026 End 1:00 PM, Thursday, 12th February 2026 Duration 24 hours Day 1 (Wed) Offline - On-campus participation Day 2 (Thu) Remote - Work from anywhere Team Size 1-4 members Levels 3 (based on year of study) Winners 1 per level Themes College Utility, Education, Health, Career, Security

Important: Submission Deadline

All submissions must be completed by 1:00 PM on Thursday, 12th February 2026. Late submissions will not be accepted.

docs.title: 🏆 Final Tips for Success
docs.text:
1. Start Simple: Get basic features working first, then add enhancements
  2. Test Frequently: Don't wait till the end to test your application
  3. Document as You Go: Write README sections as you complete features
  4. Manage Time: Allocate 2-3 hours for video creation and final testing
  5. Ask for Help: Don't hesitate to reach out to mentors
  6. Focus on Learning: This is about growth, not just winning
  7. Sleep: A 2-hour power nap is better than buggy code from exhaustion
  8. Have Fun: Enjoy the process and learn from others!

Good luck, and happy hacking! 🚀

Remember: The goal is not just to build a project, but to learn, experiment, and push your boundaries. Every line of code you write is a step forward in your journey.

docs.title: Frequently Asked Questions
docs.text: Common questions about the hackathon, answered.

docs.title: Q1: Can I use AI tools like ChatGPT or Copilot?
docs.text:
Yes, but with understanding.

Using AI for code suggestions is allowed, but you must understand every line of code you submit. Blind copy-paste without understanding will be penalized during evaluation.

Best Practice

Use AI tools to learn and understand concepts, not just to generate code. You should be able to explain any part of your code if asked.

docs.title: Q2: Do I need to deploy my application?
docs.text:
Not mandatory, but highly recommended.

Deployed applications receive bonus points and show initiative. It also makes it easier for judges to test your application.

Recommended platforms:

Type Platforms Frontend Vercel, Netlify, GitHub Pages Backend Railway, Render, Heroku Full-stack Vercel, Railway Databases MongoDB Atlas, PlanetScale, Supabase

docs.title: Q3: Can I use existing libraries and frameworks?
docs.text:
Yes! Use frameworks and libraries freely. However, core business logic should be your own.

Allowed Examples UI libraries React, Vue, Bootstrap, Tailwind Backend frameworks Express, Flask, Django Database ORMs Prisma, SQLAlchemy, Mongoose Utility libraries Lodash, Moment.js, NumPy

What Should Be Your Own

The matching algorithm, recommendation logic, or core business rules should be your implementation, not copied from tutorials.

docs.title: Q4: What if I don't finish all features?
docs.text:
Focus on making core features work perfectly rather than having many half-working features.

A smaller, polished project scores better than an incomplete ambitious one.

MVP Approach

  1. Identify the 3-4 most important features
  2. Build them completely
  3. Test thoroughly
  4. Add more features if time permits

docs.title: Q5: Can I use pre-built templates or boilerplates?
docs.text:
Level Policy Level 1 Templates and boilerplates allowed Level 2 Templates and boilerplates allowed Level 3 More original architecture expected

Credit Your Sources

Always credit where you got templates or starter code from in your README.

docs.title: Q6: How will the video be evaluated?
docs.text:
Videos should be clear, concise, and technical.

Focus on:

  • What problem you're solving
  • How you solved it technically
  • Challenges you faced
  • Key technical decisions

Avoid:

  • Long introductions
  • Reading from script robotically
  • Not showing actual working demo
  • Excessive slides instead of demo

docs.title: Q7: What programming language should I use?
docs.text:
Use whatever you're comfortable with or want to learn.

Language Good For Python Rapid development, ML/AI, data processing JavaScript Web apps, full-stack, real-time features TypeScript Type safety, larger projects Java Enterprise applications, Android Go High performance, APIs Rust Systems programming, security

Recommendation

Python and JavaScript are popular for rapid development, but any language is acceptable.

docs.title: Q8: Can I work on a problem from a lower level?
docs.text:
Your Year Can Attempt First Year Level 1, 2, or 3 Second Year Level 2 or 3 Third Year Level 3 only

Choose based on your comfort and learning goals. First years are encouraged to challenge themselves with higher levels if they're confident!

docs.title: Q9: What if my idea for Open Innovation is too ambitious?
docs.text:
Scope it down to a Minimum Viable Product (MVP) that demonstrates the core concept.

It's better to have a working simple version than an incomplete complex one.

How to scope down:

  1. Identify the ONE core feature that defines your project
  2. Build that feature completely
  3. Add supporting features only if time permits
  4. Document what you would build with more time

docs.title: Q10: How important is UI/UX?
docs.text:
Level UI/UX Weight Level 1 15% (moderately important) Level 2 Less weight but still matters Level 3 Less weight but still matters

A clean, functional UI is preferred over fancy animations.

UI Priorities

  1. Functionality first - does it work?
  2. Usability - can users figure it out?
  3. Aesthetics - does it look professional?

docs.title: Judges Guide
docs.text:
Thank you for taking the time to evaluate student submissions for the Ctrl C + Ctrl V Hackathon. We truly appreciate your expertise and guidance in assessing our students' work.

This document provides an overview of the evaluation criteria and suggested workflow to help streamline the remote judging process. Please feel free to adapt the process as you see fit.

docs.title: Judge Assignments
docs.text: Level Judges Submissions Level 1 3 judges First year student projects Level 2 & 3 3 judges (shared) Second and third year student projects

docs.title: What You'll Receive
docs.text:
Each submission includes:

  • GitHub Repository Link — Public repo with source code and README
  • 5-Minute Video Presentation — Uploaded to Google Drive

docs.title: Step 1: Watch the Video (~5 minutes)
docs.text:
Some aspects you may wish to consider:

  • Is the problem clearly explained?
  • Is there a working demo (not just slides)?
  • Are technical decisions justified?
  • Is the presentation within the time limit?

Note

Students were advised to show working features rather than slides. A functional demo, even if rough, may indicate stronger technical work.

docs.title: Step 2: Review the GitHub Repository (~5-10 minutes)
docs.text:
Some areas that may be helpful to review:

Area Considerations README Project explanation, setup instructions, screenshots Code Structure Organization, meaningful file names Code Quality Readability, comments, handling of sensitive data Commit History Development progression over time Dependencies Proper dependency management (requirements.txt, package.json, etc.)

docs.title: Step 3: Clone & Test (Optional)
docs.text:
If you would like to verify functionality beyond what the video demonstrates:

  1. Clone the repository
  2. Follow setup instructions in README
  3. Test core features
  4. Note any setup issues or bugs

Environment Considerations

Differences in OS or software versions may occasionally cause setup issues. In such cases, the video demonstration may serve as the primary reference for functionality.

docs.title: Step 4: Score Each Criterion
docs.text: The scoring rubrics below outline the evaluation criteria for each level. These are provided as guidelines to help ensure consistency across evaluations.

docs.title: Level 1: First Year Students
docs.text: Criteria Weight 1-3 (Poor) 4-6 (Average) 7-8 (Good) 9-10 (Excellent) Functionality & Correctness 40% Major features broken Some features work Most features work All features work smoothly Logic & Code Quality 30% Messy, hard to follow Basic structure Clean and readable Well-organized, good practices User Interface & Experience 15% Unusable or ugly Functional but rough Clean and intuitive Polished, responsive, delightful Video Presentation 15% No demo, confusing Basic explanation Clear demo and explanation Engaging, technical depth shown

docs.title: Level 2 & 3: Second and Third Year Students (Combined)
docs.text:
Level 2 and Level 3 submissions are evaluated together using the same criteria.

Criteria Weight 1-3 (Poor) 4-6 (Average) 7-8 (Good) 9-10 (Excellent) Functionality & Correctness 30% Core broken Partially working Stable, most features work Fully functional, polished Technical Depth 30% Shallow implementation Standard tech stack Advanced concepts used Sophisticated, well-architected User Interface & Experience 20% Unusable or ugly Functional but rough Clean and intuitive Polished, responsive, delightful Video Presentation 20% No demo, confusing Basic walkthrough Good technical explanation Deep technical dive, clear architecture

Bonuses (Level 2 & 3):

Achievement Bonus Deployed/hosted application +5%

docs.title: Calibration (Optional)
docs.text:
If time permits, it may be helpful for judges to:

  1. Review 1-2 sample submissions together to calibrate expectations
  2. Briefly discuss scoring standards to ensure consistency
  3. Align on penalty application if applicable

docs.title: Score Interpretation
docs.text: Score Range Meaning 9-10 Exceptional — Goes well beyond expectations 7-8 Good — Solid work, meets all requirements well 5-6 Average — Works but has notable gaps 3-4 Below Average — Major issues or incomplete 1-2 Poor — Barely functional or missing core features

docs.title: For Level 1 (3 judges)
docs.text:
One possible approach:

  1. Each judge evaluates approximately one-third of submissions independently
  2. Flag top 5-10 submissions for cross-review
  3. All judges review the flagged submissions
  4. Brief discussion to finalize rankings for top positions

docs.title: For Level 2 & 3 (3 judges)
docs.text:
One possible approach:

  1. Each judge evaluates all submissions independently
  2. Identify any submissions where scores differ significantly
  3. Discuss and reach consensus on those cases
  4. Final score may be averaged across judges

docs.title: Scoresheet Template
docs.text:
For each submission, record:

Field Entry Team Name Level GitHub Link Video Link Criterion 1 Score /10 Criterion 2 Score /10 Criterion 3 Score /10 Criterion 4 Score /10 Weighted Total /100 Comments Feedback/Advice for Team

docs.title: Points to Note
docs.text:
Areas of Concern

These may warrant closer examination:

  • Single bulk commit (may indicate last-minute work)
  • Video shows features not present in code
  • Over-reliance on AI-generated code without demonstrated understanding
  • Hardcoded API keys or credentials in repository

docs.title: Final Deliberation
docs.text:
For determining the top teams in each level, we would be grateful if judges could:

  1. Participate in a brief video call to discuss finalists
  2. Share observations on each top submission
  3. Collaboratively finalize rankings
  4. Provide brief reasoning for winners (to be used in announcements)

docs.title: Video Presentation Guidelines
docs.text:
What Makes a Good Video

  • Be concise: Stay within the 5-minute limit
  • Show, don't tell: Demonstrate working features
  • Explain decisions: Why did you choose this approach?
  • Be technical: Judges want to see your understanding

What to Avoid

  • Long introductions
  • Reading from a script robotically
  • Not showing actual working demo
  • Spending too much time on slides instead of demo

docs.title: Recommended Video Structure
docs.text: Section Duration Content Problem Overview 30 seconds What problem are you solving? Solution Demo 2-3 minutes Live demonstration of your application Technical Explanation 1-2 minutes Key features, technologies, challenges, architecture

docs.title: Technical Guidelines
docs.text: Follow these best practices to ensure your project is well-structured, secure, and maintainable.

docs.title: Naming Conventions
docs.text:
• Use meaningful variable and function names
  • Be consistent with naming style (camelCase, snake_case, etc.)
  • Names should describe what the variable/function does
# ❌ Bad
def f(x):
    return x * 2

# ✅ Good
def calculate_double_value(number):
    return number * 2

docs.title: Function Design
docs.text:
• Keep functions small and focused (single responsibility)
  • Comment complex logic
  • Follow consistent formatting
// ❌ Bad - one function doing too much
function handleUser(user, action, data) {
    // 200 lines of code handling multiple things
}

// ✅ Good - separate concerns
function createUser(userData) { /* ... */ }
function updateUserProfile(userId, profileData) { /* ... */ }
function deleteUser(userId) { /* ... */ }

docs.title: Commit Practices
docs.text: Do Don't Commit frequently with clear messages Make one giant commit at the end Use present tense ("Add feature" not "Added feature") Use vague messages like "fix" or "update" Group related changes in one commit Commit unrelated changes together

docs.title: Example Commit Messages
docs.text:
✅ Good commit messages:
- "Add user authentication with JWT"
- "Fix bug in expense calculation"
- "Refactor database connection handling"

❌ Bad commit messages:
- "fix"
- "update"
- "changes"
- "asdfgh"

docs.title: Security in Version Control
docs.text:
Never Commit Sensitive Data

  • API keys
  • Database passwords
  • Private keys
  • Personal credentials

Use .gitignore properly:

# Environment variables
.env
.env.local
.env.production

# IDE settings
.vscode/
.idea/

# Dependencies
node_modules/
venv/
__pycache__/

# Build outputs
dist/
build/

docs.title: README Essentials
docs.text:
Your README should answer these questions:

  1. What does this project do?
  2. Why did you build it?
  3. How do I set it up and run it?

docs.title: Minimum Documentation
docs.text:
• [x] Project title and description
  • [x] Installation instructions
  • [x] How to run the project
  • [x] List of features
  • [x] Tech stack used
  • [x] Screenshots or GIFs

docs.title: API Documentation (if applicable)
docs.text:
Document your API endpoints:

Method Endpoint Description Request Body Response GET /api/users Get all users - Array of users POST /api/users Create user {name, email} Created user PUT /api/users/:id Update user {name, email} Updated user DELETE /api/users/:id Delete user - Success message

docs.title: Input Validation
docs.text:
Always validate user inputs:

// ❌ Bad - trusting user input
function createUser(data) {
    db.insert(data);
}

// ✅ Good - validating input
function createUser(data) {
    if (!data.email || !isValidEmail(data.email)) {
        throw new Error('Invalid email address');
    }
    if (!data.name || data.name.length < 2) {
        throw new Error('Name must be at least 2 characters');
    }
    db.insert(sanitize(data));
}

docs.title: Handle Edge Cases
docs.text:
Think about what could go wrong:

  • What if the database is unavailable?
  • What if the user submits an empty form?
  • What if the API returns an error?
  • What if the file doesn't exist?

docs.title: Meaningful Error Messages
docs.text:
# ❌ Bad
raise Exception("Error")

# ✅ Good
raise ValueError("User email cannot be empty")

Don't Expose Sensitive Errors

Never show database errors or stack traces to end users. Log them internally but show a generic message to users.

docs.title: Environment Variables
docs.text:
# ❌ Bad - hardcoded in code
db_password = "supersecret123"

# ✅ Good - use environment variables
db_password = os.environ.get("DB_PASSWORD")

Create a .env.example file:

# Database
DB_HOST=localhost
DB_PORT=5432
DB_NAME=your_database
DB_USER=your_username
DB_PASSWORD=your_password

# API Keys
OPENAI_API_KEY=your_openai_key
GOOGLE_API_KEY=your_google_key

# App Settings
SECRET_KEY=your_secret_key
DEBUG=false

docs.title: Input Sanitization
docs.text:
Prevent injection attacks:

# ❌ Bad - SQL injection vulnerability
query = f"SELECT * FROM users WHERE email = '{email}'"

# ✅ Good - parameterized query
query = "SELECT * FROM users WHERE email = %s"
cursor.execute(query, (email,))

docs.title: Authentication
docs.text:
• Use established libraries (don't roll your own auth)
  • Hash passwords (bcrypt, argon2)
  • Use HTTPS in production
  • Implement proper session management

docs.title: Problem Statement 1.1: Mental Health Check-In & Wellness Tracker
docs.text: Category: Health & Wellness

docs.title: Problem Description
docs.text: College life can be overwhelming, and students often struggle to track their mental wellness. Build a supportive application that helps students monitor their daily mood, stress levels, and sleep patterns to develop better self-awareness.

docs.title: Core Features
docs.text: Feature Description 📊 Daily mood check-in Emoji/scale selection (1-10) 💭 Journal entry Optional notes for each day 😴 Sleep tracking Hours slept 📈 Stress level logging Daily stress ratings 🔥 Mood streak tracking Consecutive days logged 📉 Trend visualizations Line/bar charts for weekly/monthly patterns 🎯 Wellness suggestions Activity suggestions based on mood patterns 🆘 Emergency resources Counselor contacts, helplines

docs.title: Technical Requirements
docs.text:
• Data persistence (store mood history)
  • Date/time handling
  • Data visualization library (Chart.js, Matplotlib, Plotly, etc.)
  • Clean, intuitive UI

docs.title: Expected Deliverables
docs.text:
• Functional web/mobile app
  • Minimum 7-day mood tracking demonstration
  • At least 3 visualization types

docs.title: Bonus Features
docs.text:
• Weekly wellness summary/report
  • Reminder notifications for daily check-ins
  • Export mood data as PDF/CSV
  • Dark mode

docs.title: Problem Statement 1.2: Campus Event Discovery & Registration Platform
docs.text: Category: College Utility

docs.title: Problem Description
docs.text: Students often miss out on campus events due to poor communication and scattered information. Create a centralized platform where students can discover events, register for them, and organizers can manage attendees.

docs.title: Core Features
